Award.AbstractNarration:
I/UCRC for Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS)

1161036 Brigham Young University; Tim McLain
1161029 University of Colorado at Boulder; Eric Frew

The Center for Unmanned Aircraft Systems (CUAS) will investigate and develop new algorithms, architectures, and operational procedures for unmanned aircraft systems. Brigham Young University (BYU) and the University of Colorado at Boulder (UCB) are collaborating to establish the proposed center, with BYU as the lead institution.

The development of UAS is critical to national security, and CUAS aims to be the focal point for discovery and disseminating information about UAS of all sizes, from micro to large. The proposed Center has identified some of the challenges to overcome in order to establish UAS dominance in the US. The research led by the Center will lead to new concepts, technologies, insights, and tools for UAS; and will facilitate the transfer of these ideas to industry. The proposed center will contribute to the advancement of the UAS community through cutting-edge, industrially relevant research at the center's universities and by training the next generation of technical leaders inn the UAS field.

The broader impacts of the Center include curriculum design, community outreach and training the next generation of UAS researchers. BYU and UCB will work with industry and government sponsors to provide opportunities to students to work on high-impact, cutting-edge research relevant to industry and government labs. The Center also plans to attract women and under-represented minority groups as students in the Center. The center plans to have a significant impact on UAS curriculum through course design, textbooks, laboratory exercises, and senor design experiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Center for Unmanned Aircraft Systems (C-UAS) was established in 2012 and is an Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) involving Brigham Young University, the University of Colorado at Boulder, Virginia Tech, and the University of Michigan. The center is the only National Science Foundation-funded unmanned aircraft research center.

The core purpose of C-UAS is to provide innovative solutions to key technical challenges and superb training for future leaders in the unmanned aircraft systems industry.  Industry member benefits include control and access to all C-UAS research, dramatic leverage of R&D funds through pooled resources with other industry members, augmented internal R&D with cost-effective, highly-skilled graduate student researchers, and relationships with world-class faculty researchers and top graduate students/future employees.

We have demonstrated ability to fly through and map cluttered terrain where GPS is intermittent or unavailable using methods that are both consistent and observable. These methods hold significant promise for implementation with large-scale multivehicle systems.

We have developed the ability for small unmanned aircraft to sense and avoid other aircraft in the airspace. We have developed and demonstrated a custom radar design for sense and avoid (SAA) that is suitable for the size, weight, and power requirements of small unmanned aircraft. We have developed avoidance algorithms well matched to the characteristics of the custom radar design. We have demonstrated SAA using this radar with a multiple intruder aircraft.

We have developed and demonstrated flight path optimization algorithms that improve the fidelity and resolution of aerial imagery and maps obtained from unmanned aircraft. These methods will lead to more efficient gathering of aerial imagery for the purposes of creating high resolution three-dimensional maps.

BYU has developed one of the smallest, lightest, and cheapest phased array radars ever demonstrated for UAS sense and avoid. Phased array radars are normally expensive units only affordable for military aircraft or air traffic control, and are too heavy and bulky to fly on small UAS. The BYU sense and avoid radar weighs 120 grams and consumes 10 watts, and is able to electronically scan its look direction to locate and track aircraft in both range and angle using digital beamforming. The radar sensor allows a UAS to compute an avoidance path to change course and avoid collisions with other manned and unmanned aircraft, solving a key open grand challenge in integrating UAS into the national airspace. We received an NSF MRI award to continue the development of this sense and avoid radar system with the particular objective of supporting UAS research and development for our university and industry partners.

A primary outcome of our center's work is the corps of well-trained and motivated students that are poised to have a significant impact on the emerging UAS industry.
